sen.j: 千 道安（せん の どうあん、天文 (元号)15年（1546年） - 慶長12年2月17日 (旧暦)（1607年3月14日））は戦国時代 (日本)から江戸時代初期の茶道。
sen.e: Doan SEN (1546 - March 14, 1607), a Japanese tea ceremony master during the Sengoku and Edo periods of Japanese history.
sen.cmt: 原文の「茶道」は、正しくは「茶人」だと思われます。
sen.e: Doan SEN (1546 - March 14, 1607), a Japanese tea ceremony master during the Sengoku and Edo periods of Japanese history.
Doan SEN (1546 - March 14, 1607), a Japanese tea ceremony master during the Sengoku and Edo periods of Japanese history.

sen.j: 始め紹安。
sen.e: He was originally named Shoan.
He was originally named Shoan.
He was originally named Shoan.

sen.j: 後に道安。
sen.e: His name was later changed to Doan.
His name was later changed to Doan.
His name was later changed to Doan.

sen.j: 号は、可休斎、不休斎、眠翁、泉南道安老人など。
sen.e: His tea names were Kakyusai, Fukyusai, Mino, and Sennandoanrojin.
His tea names were Kakyusai, Fukyusai, Mino, and Sennandoanrojin.
His tea names were Kakyusai, Fukyusai, Mino, and Sennandoanrojin.

sen.j: 堺千家の主。
sen.e: He was the head of the Sakai-Senke (Sakai Sen House).
He was the head of the Sakai-Senke (Sakai Sen House).
He was the head of the Sakai-Senke (Sakai Sen House).

sen.j: 略歴
sen.e: Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History

sen.j: 天文15年（1546年）、千利休の長男として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in 1546, the first son of SEN no Rikyu.
He was born in 1546, the first son of SEN no Rikyu.
He was born in 1546, the first son of SEN no Rikyu.

sen.j: 母は宝心妙樹。
sen.e: His mother was Hoshin Myoju.
His mother was Hoshin Myoju.
His mother was Hoshin Myoju.

sen.j: 千家の嫡男だが、利休と折り合いが悪く若い頃に家を出た。
sen.e: Although he was the natural heir of the Sen Family, he had disagreements with Rikyu and left home at an early age.
Although he was a legitimate son of the Sen Family, he had disagreements with Rikyu and left home at an early age.
sen.cmt: 嫡男は、a legitimate son に訂正しました。
sen.e: Although he was a legitimate son of the Sen Family, he had disagreements with Rikyu and left home at an early age.

sen.j: のちに利休と和解。
sen.e: Later he was reconciled with Rikyu.
Later he was reconciled with Rikyu.
Later he was reconciled with Rikyu.

sen.j: 茶の道を修め豊臣秀吉の茶頭八人衆に数えられるまでになった。
sen.e: He mastered the "Way of Tea" (the Japanese tea ceremony) and became one of the Eight Tea Masters of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
He mastered the "Way of Tea" (the Japanese tea ceremony) and became one of the Eight Tea Masters of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
He mastered the "Way of Tea" (the Japanese tea ceremony) and became one of the Eight Tea Masters of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 利休切腹後は金森長近に預けられ（異説あり）、蟄居、謹慎を命じられた。
sen.e: After Rikyu's ritual suicide, he was said to have been left with Nagachika KANAMORI (though there is a contrary view to this), where he was ordered to stay inside in disciplinary confinement.
sen.cmt: 「金森長近」はKanamori Nagachika や、 Nagachika Kanamori と2通りに記されているようです。ここではNagachikaKANAMORI としました。
sen.e: After Rikyu's Seppuku (ritual suicide), he was said to have been placed with Nagachika KANAMORI (though there is a different view to this), where he was ordered to stay inside in disciplinary confinement.
sen.cmt: 切腹については、統一用語でＳｅｐｐｕｋｕを使用するよう指示があるため、追記しました。 Left with を placed with に訂正しました。 Contrary view より different view のほうが一般的だと思い訂正しました。
sen.e: After Rikyu's Seppuku (ritual suicide), he was said to have been placed with Nagachika KANAMORI (though there is a different view to this), where he was ordered to stay inside in disciplinary confinement.

sen.j: 長近が茶人であったことから、親交を深めたとみられている。
sen.e: Since Nagachika was a master of tea ceremony as well, their friendship presumably grew deeper.
Since Nagachika was a master of tea ceremony as well, their friendship presumably grew deeper.
Since Nagachika was a master of tea ceremony as well, their friendship presumably grew deeper.

sen.j: 文禄3年（1594年）に赦されて堺市に戻り（時期には諸説ある）、千家の家督を継いだ（堺千家）。
sen.e: In 1594, he was granted a pardon and returned to Sakai City (though various theories exist as to the time of his return), where he took the reins of the Sakai-Senke, the main branch of the Sen Family
In 1594, he was granted a pardon and returned to Sakai City (though various theories exist as to the time of his return), where he succeeded as the head of the Sen Family (Sakai-Senke).
sen.cmt: 原文に無い情報を付け足していたので、原文通りの訳に訂正しました。また、家督の部分も訂正しました。
sen.e: In 1594, he was granted a pardon and returned to Sakai City (though various theories exist as to the time of his return), where he succeeded as the head of the Sen Family (Sakai-Senke).

sen.j: 慶長6年（1601年）、細川忠興に招かれ、茶頭となり、豊前国水崎で三百石を拝領する。
sen.e: In 1601, upon the invitation of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, he became Tadaoki's tea master and was bestowed three hundred koku in Misaki, Buzen Province.
sen.cmt: 「細川忠興」はTadaoki Hosokawaや、 Hosokawa Tadaoki と、2通りに記されているようです。ここではTadaoki HOSOKAWAとしました。
sen.e: In 1601, upon the invitation of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, he became Tadaoki's sado (person in charge of the tea ceremony) and was bestowed three hundred koku in Misaki, Buzen Province.
sen.cmt: 茶頭は、共有用語の、sado (person in charge of the tea ceremony)のほうに訂正しました。
sen.e: In 1601, upon the invitation of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, he became Tadaoki's sado (person in charge of the tea ceremony) and was bestowed three hundred koku in Misaki, Buzen Province.

sen.j: 慶長12年（1607年）、豊前の地にて死去（異説あり）。
sen.e: In 1607, he died on the land of Buzen Province (though there is a contrary view to this).
In 1607, he died on the land of Buzen Province (though there is a different view to this).
sen.cmt: contrary view を different view に訂正しました
sen.e: In 1607, he died on the land of Buzen Province (though there is a different view to this).

sen.j: 人物評
sen.e: Doan as a Person and His Episodes
Doan as a Person and His Episodes
Doan as a Person and His Episodes

sen.j: 同い年と言うことから、義弟である千少庵との対比で語られることが多い。
sen.e: When he is mentioned, he is often compared with his younger brother-in-law, Shoan SEN, because they were the same age.
When he is mentioned, he is often compared with his younger brother-in-law, Shoan SEN, because they were the same age.
When he is mentioned, he is often compared with his younger brother-in-law, Shoan SEN, because they were the same age.

sen.j: 中には少庵を道安より優れていたように描く逸話もあるが、これは現存しているのが少庵系統の三千家周辺のものである事実を考慮する必要がある。
sen.e: Some anecdotes picture Shoan having better skill at Japanese tea ceremony than Doan, but one needs to consider the fact that only the san-Senke (three Sen Families) of the Shoan lineage exist today.
Some anecdotes picture Shoan having better skill at Japanese tea ceremony than Doan, but one needs to consider the fact that only the san-Senke (three Sen Families) of the Shoan lineage exist today.
Some anecdotes picture Shoan having better skill at Japanese tea ceremony than Doan, but one needs to consider the fact that only the san-Senke (three Sen Families) of the Shoan lineage exist today.

sen.j: そうした資料の中でも道安についての賞賛が散見されるところから、当時際だった才能を発揮していたことが伺われる。
sen.e: Among such historical materials, there often appear words of praise for Doan, inferring he had demonstrated his exceptional skill in those days.
sen.cmt: 原文の「伺う」は正しくは「窺う」だと思われます。
sen.e: Among such historical materials, there often appear words of praise for Doan, inferring he had demonstrated his exceptional skill in those days.
Among such historical materials, there often appear words of praise for Doan, inferring he had demonstrated his exceptional skill in those days.

sen.j: 少庵は先天的に足に不自由があったが、これが三千家系統の資料では道安に置き換えるなどの事実関係の齟齬も確認されている。
sen.e: There have been some confirmed contradictions between the historical materials belonging to the san Senke and fact, such as the case in which the person with a congenital leg impairment was Shoan in reality whereas in a san-Senke material it was replaced as Doan.

There have been some confirmed contradictions between the historical materials belonging to the san Senke and fact, such as the case in which the person with a congenital leg impairment was Shoan in reality whereas in a san-Senke material it was replaced as Doan.

There have been some confirmed contradictions between the historical materials belonging to the san Senke and fact, such as the case in which the person with a congenital leg impairment was Shoan in reality whereas in a san-Senke material it was replaced as Doan.

sen.j: 利休が二人に竹の蓋置を選ばせたところ、道安は節のついたゴツゴツとした蓋置を、少庵は節のない滑らかな蓋置を選んだというエピソードがあり、道安は磊落な性格、少庵は繊細な性格であったとされている（『江岑夏書』）。
sen.e: There is an interesting story about the two, when they were asked by Rikyu to each pick a bamboo rest for a teakettle lid, and Doan picked a rugged one with bamboo joints, while Shoan chose a smooth one without any joints, suggesting that Doan had a open-hearted personality in contrast to Shoan's delicate one. (the "Koshin Gegaki")

There is an interesting story about the two, when they were asked by Rikyu to each pick a bamboo rest for a teakettle lid, and Doan picked a rugged one with bamboo joints, while Shoan chose a smooth one without any joints, suggesting that Doan had a open-hearted personality in contrast to Shoan's delicate one. (the "Koshin Gegaki")

There is an interesting story about the two, when they were asked by Rikyu to each pick a bamboo rest for a teakettle lid, and Doan picked a rugged one with bamboo joints, while Shoan chose a smooth one without any joints, suggesting that Doan had a open-hearted personality in contrast to Shoan's delicate one (the "Koshin Gegaki").
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を変更しました。

sen.j: 秀吉が利休に「大仏（方広寺）の内陣を囲いて茶の湯すべき者は誰ぞ」と尋ねたところ、「道安が仕るべき」と道安を推挙したとの逸話が残されている（『茶話指月集』）。
sen.e: There remains a story in which Hideyoshi asked Rikyu, "Who should performed a tea ceremony around the inner sanctuary of the Great Buddha (at the Hoko-ji Temple)?", to which Rikyu replied, "Doan should.", recommending Doan. (the "Sawa Shigetsu shu", a verbatim collection of Sotan SEN's talks about tea, written by Yoken FUJIMURA and edited by Soan KUSUMI.)
sen.cmt: 定訳・対訳コラムにGenpaku Sotanとありますが、千 宗旦（せん そうたん）が正しいと思われます。
sen.e: There remains a story in which Hideyoshi asked Rikyu, "Who should performed a tea ceremony around the inner sanctuary of the Great Buddha (at the Hoko-ji Temple)?", to which Rikyu replied, "Doan should.", recommending Doan. ("Sawa Shigetsu shu" (a collection of Genpaku Sotan's talks about tea)).
sen.cmt: 本のタイトルのみに訂正しました。
sen.e: There remains a story in which Hideyoshi asked Rikyu, "Who should performed a tea ceremony around the inner sanctuary of the Great Buddha (at the Hoko-ji Temple)?", to which Rikyu replied, "Doan should.", recommending Doan ("Sawa Shigetsu shu" [a collection of Genpaku Sotan's talks about tea]).
sen.cmt: 括弧とピリオドの位置を変更しました。

sen.j: 道安の茶会に招かれた利休が亭主を待つ間「露地の飛び石の据え方がひとつだけ高い」と話したところ、勝手で聴いていた道安は中立ちの間に的確に直したという（前掲書）。
sen.e: It is said that when Rikyu was invited to a Doan's tea gathering, he said while waiting for the host, "One of the stepping stones (tobi-ishi) in the tea garden (roji) is positioned too high.", which Doan had heard in the kitchen, and he corrected it during the intermission (nakadachi). (the "Sawa Shigetsu shu")

It is said that when Rikyu was invited to a Doan's tea gathering, he said while waiting for the host, "One of the stepping stones (tobi-ishi) in the tea garden (roji) is positioned too high.", which Doan had heard in katte (a place used to cook and prepare food in upper class residences), and he corrected it during the intermission (nakadachi). (the "Sawa Shigetsu shu")
sen.cmt: 勝手は、指定されている単語katte (a place used to cook and prepare food in upper class residences)に訂正しました。勝手とkitchen は、全く同じではないと思いましたので。
sen.e: It is said that when Rikyu was invited to a Doan's tea gathering, he said while waiting for the host, "One of the stepping stones (tobi-ishi) in the tea garden (roji) is positioned too high.", which Doan had heard in katte (a place used to cook and prepare food in upper class residences), and he corrected it during the intermission (nakadachi) (the "Sawa Shigetsu shu").
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を変更しました。

sen.j: 千家再興の後、秀吉に呼ばれた道安が御前で茶を点てたところ、秀吉は「宗易が手前によく似たる」と褒めた（前掲書）。
sen.e: After the restoration of the SEN family, when Doan made tea in front of the Emperor upon the invitation of Hideyoshi, Hideyoshi praised him, saying, "You bear a close resemblance to Soeki (Rikyu's Buddhist name)." (the"Sawa Shigetsu shu")

After the restoration of the SEN family, when Doan made tea in front of the Emperor upon the invitation of Hideyoshi, Hideyoshi praised him, saying, "You bear a close resemblance to Soeki (Rikyu's Buddhist name)." (the"Sawa Shigetsu shu")

After the restoration of the SEN family, when Doan made tea in front of the Emperor upon the invitation of Hideyoshi, Hideyoshi praised him, saying, "You bear a close resemblance to Soeki (Rikyu's Buddhist name)." (the"Sawa Shigetsu shu")

sen.j: 茶人としての事績及び評価
sen.e: Achievements as a Master of Tea Ceremony and Public Evaluations
Achievements as a Master of Tea Ceremony and Public Evaluations
Achievements as a Master of Tea Ceremony and Public Evaluations

sen.j: 少庵の茶を静とするならば、道安の茶は動であると言う評がある。
sen.e: Some view if Shoan's tea is considered "stillness", then Doan's tea is "movement".
People say if Shoan's tea is considered "stillness", then Doan's tea is "movement".
sen.cmt: some view を people say にしました。
sen.e: People say if Shoan's tea is considered "stillness", then Doan's tea is "movement".

sen.j: 創作意欲が旺盛であり、その工夫は簡素さの中に力強さを求めるものであったようである。
sen.e: It seems he was full of creative enthusiasm and came up with ideas to seek strength within simplicity.
It seems he was full of creative enthusiasm and came up with ideas to seek strength within simplicity.
It seems he was full of creative enthusiasm and came up with ideas to seek strength within simplicity.

sen.j: 道安が金属片を使って灰をならしていたのが、金属製の灰匙の始まりだと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that metal ash spoons (haisaji) originated when Doan had used a metal piece to level ash.
It is said that metal ash spoons (haisaji) originated when Doan had used a metal piece to level ash.
It is said that metal ash spoons (haisaji) originated when Doan had used a metal piece to level ash.

sen.j: 塗り蓋を拭いてから茶巾をおく手前は、道安が始めた物と言われている。
sen.e: Doan is said to have created the procedure of wiping a lacquered lid with a tea cloth (chakin) before placing the tea cloth on the lid.
Doan is said to have created the procedure of wiping a lacquered lid with a tea cloth (chakin) before placing the tea cloth on the lid.
Doan is said to have created the procedure of wiping a lacquered lid with a tea cloth (chakin) before placing the tea cloth on the lid.

sen.j: 道安囲、道安風呂の考案。
sen.e: He also created the Doan-gakoi (enclosure) and the Doan-buro (portable brazier).
He also created the Doan-gakoi (enclosure) and the Doan-buro (portable brazier).
He also created the Doan-gakoi (enclosure) and the Doan-buro (portable brazier).

sen.j: 代表的な弟子
sen.e: Primary Disciples
Leading Disciples of Doan SEN
Leading Disciples of Doan SEN

sen.j: 桑山貞晴（宗仙）：大和国御所藩主。
sen.e: Sadaharu KUWAYAMA (also known by his Buddhist name, Sosen), a Gose Domain leader in Yamato Province.
Sadaharu KUWAYAMA (also known by his Buddhist name, Sosen), the lord of Gose Domain in Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: leader を the lord of Gose Domain に訂正しました。
sen.e: Sadaharu KUWAYAMA (also known by his Buddhist name, Sosen), the lord of Gose Domain in Yamato Province.

sen.j: 片桐貞昌の師。
sen.e: He was a teacher of Sadamasa KATAGIRI.
He was a teacher of Sadamasa KATAGIRI.
He was a teacher of Sadamasa KATAGIRI.

sen.j: 金森可重（雲州）：秀吉・徳川家康に仕えた武人。
sen.e: Arishige KANAMORI (also known as Unshu KANAMORI), a warrior who served Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
Arishige KANAMORI (also known as Unshu KANAMORI), a warrior who served Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
Arishige KANAMORI (also known as Unshu KANAMORI), a warrior who served Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 金森重近（宗和）の実父であり道安と交流があったのは確かであるが、茶の湯の師は古田重然であったともされる。
sen.e: He was the biological father of Shigechika KANAMORI (also known as Sowa KANAMORI), and while his exchange with Doan is for certain, some suggest his tea ceremony teacher was actually Shigenari FURUTA.

He was the biological father of Shigechika KANAMORI (also known as Sowa KANAMORI), and while his exchange with Doan is for certain, some suggest his tea ceremony teacher was actually Shigenari FURUTA.

He was the biological father of Shigechika KANAMORI (also known as Sowa KANAMORI), and while his exchange with Doan is for certain, some suggest his tea ceremony teacher was actually Shigenari FURUTA.
